awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear and Inertial Magnetic Structures in Emhd Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made in response to a proposal submitted to and reviewed under the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering joint solicitation NSF 09-596. The award provides funds to support the broader impact activity of dissemination of research results by participation in annual conferences. The overall research effort, which does not support this broader impact activity, is being funded separately by the DOE under contract to UCLA (Grant DE-FG02-10ER55081).

Research on magnetic holes and bubbles in dense plasmas will be performed. These are depletions and enhancements of magnetic fields in plasmas produced by nonlinear effects. Such structures exist in many plasmas from astrophysical to nanometer scales. In the laboratory the physics of these phenomena will be studied under controlled conditions. Bubbles and holes will be investigated in a parameter regime called electron magnetohydrodynamics, where only the electrons interact with the magnetic field, but not the ions, while both species are coupled via space charge electric fields. This leads to many unexplored electromagnetic effects which are of interest in magnetic reconnection, turbulence, particle acceleration and heating. Specifically, the proposed experiments will induce localized magnetic fields with loop antennas driven by pulsed or oscillatory currents. Magnetic holes are generated when the induced plasma field cancels an ambient field. Magnetic bubbles in unmagnetized plasmas are produced when the induced plasma field is strong enough to magnetize the electrons and allow whistler modes to exist inside the bubble.

The study of magnetic holes and bubbles is new and fundamental and has potential impact on many areas in plasma physics. The proposed research benefits society through discoveries which also lead to practical applications. For example, ongoing research into helicity properties of whistler vortices led to the development of a novel directional antenna which could be used in space to transmit or receive signals in a preferred direction. Comparable research is only performed in Russia.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Nonlinear magnetic structures and bubbles have been studied in plasmas. Nonlinearities arise when plasma per- turbations are comparable to average plasma properties. ”Bubbles” are regions of localized enhanced or depleted parameters in magnetic field or densities compared to the ambient parameters. The plasma parameter regime can be described by magnetized electrons and unmagnetized ions, called electron magneto hydrodynamics. Magnetic perturbations are produced with pulsed currents through magnetic loops or pulsed current collection by electrodes. Fields and currents propagate as whistler modes which explains the slow penetration of pulsed currents into plasmas. Nonlinear effects arise when the wave magnetic field is comparable to the uniform background field. It can create regions of zero magnetic field. A most interesting nonlinear structure is that of magnetic vortex which propagates and is appropriately called a ”whistler spheromak”. The net field lines are locally twisted and twist propagates along and against a uniform background field. The propagation direction depends on the magnetic helicity. The wave speed varies with magnetic field strength. The magnetic energy of the whistler vortex is gradually converted into electron thermal energy by magnetic reconnection or annihilation. Anisotropic heating creates secondary whistler instabili- ties. Such processes may also occur in space and fusion plasmas during whistler-mediated reconnection. Merging of counter-propagating vortices creates a stationary field-reversed configuration. Three-dimensional magnetic null points form magnetic bubbles. When the gradient scale length of the magnetic field is comparable to the wavelength of the whistler mode the field properties cannot be described by Fourier analysis with linear plane waves. Thus experiments of wave propagation near magnetic X and O-type null points have been performed. When a parallel whistler mode propagates on strongly curved field lines it changes into a highly oblique mode. Group and phase velocities have different directions. It has been observed that most of the wave energy flows along the curved field while the phases propagate across the field, known as a Gendrin mode in uniform fields.
Besides magnetic bubbles plasma density bubbles have also been investigated. These are typically spherical discharge plasmas confined by an electric field created by a double layer or sheath on a grid. Plasma bubbles often attach to positively biased electrodes as ”fireballs” which changes the current collection dramatically which is important for probes and current collectors in space. Spherical grids of high transparency are also used to create density bubbles of enhanced or depleted densities. Particles accelerated in a localized electric field create transit time sheath instabilities. Their properties have been studied carefully since they can be easily confused with instabilities in the plasma volume. Sheath instabilities arise near the ion plasma frequency when an ion rich sheath is so strongly depleted of electrons that it forms a virtual anode. In the presence of a magnetic field electrons drift around a positively biased electrode which creates electron drift mode instabilities. When a magnetized electrode is biased strongly negative the ion bombardment releases secondary electrons which forms a ”magnetron” discharge. It is useful for sputtering and coating applications. The plasma exhibits instabilities which have been investigated. These are important for understanding the anomalous electron transport in cross-field discharges. In summary, the basic research has discovered new phenomena which are relevant to practical applications.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2013
Modified by: Reiner L Stenzel
